titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Florencio Asenjo Collection, 1945-2013 UA.90.F105
titlestmt.author: Juan Fernando Velasquez Ospina and Jim Cassaro.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:12:23 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The collection documents the musical career of Florencio Asenjo, and contains manuscript sketches and first and final versions of all of the composer's musical output, mostly for orchestra or chamber ensemble. In addition, correspondence, audio recordings, and clippings from the musical press are included.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 1926, Asenjo was a mathematician who came from Argentina to the United States in 1958. He was professor on the faculty at several American universities, including Georgetown, Southern Illinois, and the University of Pittsburgh, where he was associate professor of mathematics from 1963 to 2010. Asenjo also had intellectual interests in other areas such as philosophy—especially phenomenology—art history, aesthetics, and especially music. During his youth Mr. Asenjo studied piano, composition, and conducting with the Spanish composer Jaime Pahissa (1880-1969) in Buenos Aires.

Asenjo´s musical output is principally in symphonic repertoire, and has been performed by orchestras and musical ensembles like the Eastman Philharmonic, Eastman Wind Ensemble, U.S. Air Force Band, American University Orchestra, La Plata Symphony Orchestra, Slovak National Symphony Orchestra, the Bulgarian Philharmonia, and the Warsaw National Philharmonic Orchestra. Despite some commercial recordings made in the last ten years by Albany Records, the music of Florencio G. Asenjo is relatively unknown to researchers, musicians, and audiences in general.

In his music, Asenjo tries to avoid overt repetition, which he considers "overwhelming in Western music". Indeed, according to his own words, he does not "want to do repetition for repetition's sake". As a result, he experiments using the relationship between two types of contrasting themes that are commonly found in symphonies and concertos.

According to the composer, these two themes are connected in intent and aesthetic rather than in content. Thus, Asenjo saw in this dialectic contrast the opportunity to create chains of themes in his music that are aesthetically connected, retaining continuity and atmosphere. This particular approach was labeled maximalism by Asenjo, which can be described as a high density of content in constant change. Asenjo passed away in 2013 in Pittsburgh.

Scope: The collection contains sketches and the first and final versions of all of Asenjo's musical output, all for orchestra or chamber ensemble. Included are performance parts and the transparencies used to produce the parts. In addition, Asenjo's vast correspondence with other composers and conductors, among them Igor Stravinsky, Jaime Pahissa, and Ernesto Halffter, among others. Audio recordings, on reel-to-reel tapes and cassettes, by various orchestras and ensembles are also included, along with newspaper clippings of reviews of these concerts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Florencio Asenjo Collection, 1945-2013, UA.90.F105, University Archives, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Juan Fernando Velasquez Ospina and Jim Cassaro.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series: Series 1 includes music compositions that are dated and Series 2, those that are undated on the manuscripts. Series 3 includes drafts and final printed versions of articles written by Asenjo, mostly on musical topics. Series 4 includes documents on Asenjo's interaction with music publishers, newspaper articles and clippings, and contracts. Series 5 includes correspondence with other composers and conductors, documents that pertain to Asenjo's travels, and photographic images. Series 6 includes reel-to-reel and cassette tape recordings of Asenjo's works by various orchestras and ensembles, and radio interviews.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Julian Asenjo on March 24, 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The collection contains sketches and the first and final versions of all of Asenjo's musical output, all for orchestra or chamber ensemble. Included are performance parts and the transparencies used to produce the parts. In addition, Asenjo's vast correspondence with other composers and conductors, among them Igor Stravinsky, Jaime Pahissa, and Ernesto Halffter, among others. Audio recordings, on reel-to-reel tapes and cassettes, by various orchestras and ensembles are also included, along with newspaper clippings of reviews of these concerts.

did.unittitle: Preludio en Mi b Mayor; [Prelude in E Flat Major]
Variaciones Sobre un Tema de [Jaime] Pahissa; [Variations on a Theme of Pahissa]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On page 9: "17/10/1945". Theme and five variations. On the back of page 9: "Hussein Husliya"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instrument: Piano

I. Retrato [Portrait]; II. Corceles Féricos; III. Tarde de Invierno [Winter Afternoon]; IV: Cántiga para una Niña Ruborosa [cantiga for a Blushed Girl]; and V. Pequeña Fuga [Litle Fugue]. Although the title "Suite" is not indicated, the numbers on the first caption of each piece [in blue pencil] suggest an order. Date on first page: "9-1946" and last page"1946 (Junio) [1946, June]". Pasteover on mm. 8 and 9 of "Tarde de Invierno". Manuscript signed by the composer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instrument: Piano
Work dedicated to the composer's father. Date on first manuscript page: "28/10/1946."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Work dedicated to the composer's father. Date on first manuscript page: "28/10/1946."

did.unittitle: Symphony for Strings [Sinfonia para Instrumentos de Cuerda]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: String orchestra: 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass

Dates on the first page of the manuscript: composed between November 1946 and August 1948, premiered on October 11, 1953, El Teatro Argentino, La Plata, Argentina. Other performances: June 3, 1954, State Radio Symphony, Buenos Aires (conductor Bruno Bandini); February 26, 1960, The American University Orchestra, Washington D.C. (conductor: George Steiner).

did.unittitle: Orquesta Sinfonica de la Radio del Estado (LRA), Buenos Aires
The American University Orchestra, Washington D.C. [mimeograph]
Concierto para Instrumentos de Viento; [Concert for Wind Instruments]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Piccolo, 2 Flutes, 2 Oboes, English Horn, 2 B-flat Clarinets, B-flat Bass Clarinet, B-Flat Soprano Saxophone (or Clarinet), 2 Bassoons, Contrabassoon, 2 Horns in F, 2 Trumpets in B-flat, 2 Trombones, and Tuba.

Date at the end of movement II: 19 de Mayo de 1950. Premiered in January 1960 by the U.S. Air Force Band (Conductor: Harry Meuser), Washington D.C. Other performances: April 30, 1964, Eastman Wind Ensemble (Conductor: A. Clyde Roller); February 18, 1966, Brevard College Orchestra; November 23, 1975, Duquesne University Symphony Band; February 23, 1984, Carnegie Mellon Wind Ensemble.

did.unittitle: Danza de los Secretarios [Dance of the Secretaries]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: 2 Flutes, 2 Oboes, 2 Bb Clarinets, 2 Bassoons, 2 Trumpets in Bb, 2 Trombones, 2 Violin, Viola, Cello, Double bass, and Timpani.

This piece was the first of a series of sketches based on some fables by Franz Kafka. Notes on first sketch: "5 August, 1960". Notes on second sketch: "24 de Septiembre 1960." Duration indicated on second draft´s last page: 5 min, 30 sec. Premiered on April 27, 1965 by the Eastman Philharmonia (Conductor: A. Clyde Roller) in Rochester, New York. Other performances: April 8, 1976, Duquesne University Symphony (Conductor: Bernard Goldberg). This work was selected to be presented at the 35th Festival of American Music at the University of Rochester.

did.unittitle: Program of the "Thirty-Fifth Annual Festival of American Music" at the Institute of American Music and the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Flute, Oboe, Bb Clarinet, Trumpets in C, Trombone, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, Double bass, Timpani.

I. La Joie de Vivre, II. Convictions; III. Fiestas. Two wind instruments indicated in the full score manuscript. However, in the printed score only one wind instrument appears. Date on the first page of the draft of "La joie de vivre": Dec. 2, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Piccolo, Flute, Oboe, English Horn, B-flat Clarinet, Bass Clarinet, Bassoon, Contra Bassoon, Horn in F, Trumpet in B-flat, Trombone, Tuba, Timpani, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass.
Date on first page of sketch: "XI-9-67". Premiered on April 27, 1976 by Duquesne University Symphony Orchestra (Conductor: Bernard Goldberg) in Pittsburgh.

did.unittitle: Letter from Jennifer Bilfield, Executive Director of the National Orchestra Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Flute, Oboe, B-flat Clarinet, Bassoon, Horn in F, Trumpet in C, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, Double bass, and Timpani.

Name differs in print score and parts: "Instrumental Dialogues: A Symphony in Four Movements". Date on the first page of the manuscript: "July 22, 1977". Work composed between January 1, 1977 and April 29, 1979 [with a pause of ten months]. Premiered on June 5, 1981 by the Duquesne University Symphony Orchestra (Conductor: Bernard Goldberg). Other performances: February 14, 1983, University of Pittsburgh Orchestra (Conductor: Grover Wilkins).

did.unittitle: Paper with dates of composition process
Crystallizations: A Symphony in the Nascent State [Symphony No. 3]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Flute, Oboe, B-flat Clarinet, Bassoon, Horn if F, Trumpet in C, Timpani, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass.

Named as Symphony No. 3 on full score manuscript. Contents: I. Lento; II. Andante; III. Moderato. Annotations in full score manuscript: "Mar 4, 82" [on p. 1], "Feb. 21, 87" [on p. 41] and "Estoril, August 15, 1987" [on p. 119]. This work was composed over eight years. According to the notes of the composer, the first draft was written between "July 25, 1980 and April 29, 1981;" the second draft was written between "December 10, 1981 and March 2, 1982;" the final draft was written between "March 4, 1982 and August 15, 1987" [the work was interrupted between April 30, 1982 and September 7, 1986].

did.unittitle: Master copy of printed full score
Papers with dates of composition process
Receipts of copies and binding of score and parts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Flute, Oboe, Clarinet in B-flat, Bassoon, Horn in F, Trumpet in C, Trombone, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, Double bass.

Three movements. Different dates: "2010" [on manila folder that contains full score manuscript], "revised 10/23/2011" on p. 1 of printed [transposed] full score; "revised 10/16/2011" on printed parts.

did.unittitle: A Diptych of Lord Dunsany's Tales

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: solo Violin, Flute, Oboe, English horn, Clarinet in B-flat, Bass clarinet in B-flat, Bassoon, Horn in F, Trumpet in C, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass.

Two sections divided in several movements: Section I. Carcasole: I. When the world was fairier[sic]; II. The harp; III. Turning aside the dooms of fate; IV. The deeps of the forest; V. The music of bells. Section II. In the land before time: VI. The mists before the beginning; VII. Without light; VIII. The pace of things: many times or nor time. Notes on first page of printed [Transposed] score "11/28/11."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: A Thousand and One Nights: Impressions for Clarinet and Orchestra

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Flute, Oboe, B-flat Clarinet, Bassoon, Horn in F, Trumpet in C, Trombone, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass.

I. The thrall [sic] of love; II. The hermits; III. The flea and the mouse; IV. The ebony horse; V. The angel of death; VI. City of brass; VII. The lovers of Medina; VIII. The spider and the wind; IX. The quintessence of things; X. Maruf, the cobbler.
[Although the title of this work suggests that there is a clarinet soloist, there is no part for solo clarinet.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

I. Cat Cinderella; II. The old woman discovered; III. The large louse, the mouse and the cricket; IV. Pride punished; V. End of tales of tales.

Contents: I. Waltz interrupted; II. Solemn march; III. Requiem; IV. La joie de vivre; V. Rain; VI. Dialogue of time and space; VII. Venus playing; VIII. Transfigured moment; IX. Pierrot solaire.

The rooster and the dancing girl; VII. The wife of the autumn wind; VIII. Immortality; IX. The white horse; 10. Gleanings from snow country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three different sets of unidentified drafts that were written between 1955 and September 28, 2002. Date on set number 1 "6-4-55". Dates on each page of set 2 [from "August of 2001" to "September of 2002"]. The third set is a draft of a string quintet. Contains indications and comments by the composer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instruments: Orchestra: Piccolo, 2 flutes, 2 Oboe, 2 Clarinets in B-flat, 2 Bassoons, Contabasson, 4 Horns in F, 3 trumpets in C, Tuba, Timpani, 2 Violins, Viola, Cello, and Double bass.

Composition of Jaime Pahissa (1880-1969), dedicated to Manuel Roviralba "en testimonio de una vieja amistad" [as a testimony of our old friendship]. Dedicatory to Florencio Asenjo in the foreword "A mi querido Florencio, como buen amigo y excelente discípulo: Jaime Pahissa" [To my dear Florencio, as a good friend and excellent disciple: Jaime Pahissa].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article published in the quarterly Forum, summer-fall of 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The National University Eva Peron [Actual National University of La Plata]—where Florencio Asenjo was professor—and the Ministry of Education organized this arts festival in 1954. Florencio Asenjo was a member of the committee that created the program. Florencio Asenjo also participated in the Festival with the lecture "Simetría y polaridad en las matemáticas y en las artes" [Symmetry and polarity inmathematics and arts].

did.unittitle: Contract for production with Kirk Trevor
Music recordings indexed in Records International
Correspondence with Ernesto and Manuel Halffter
Correspondence regarding a cancelled competition for String Orchestra Works

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material related to a cancelled Eastman String Orchestra Competition in 1989, the material indicates that this was a polemical issue that involved a scam.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with the American Music Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcript of a program in the Latin American Radio Magazine [Revista Radial Latinoamericana] at WRCT, CMU Radio. Giovani E. Reyes, Martha E. Mantilla and Victor Cordova produced this radio program. The family also donated some tapes with the recordings.
